questions.question: Which of the following is a primary source of federal tax law?

options.B: Revenue Ruling
options.C: Tax article in a professional journal

questions.explanation: Primary sources are official pronouncements of tax law, including the Internal Revenue Code, Treasury Regulations, Revenue Rulings, Revenue Procedures, and court cases. Textbooks, articles, and IRS publications are secondary sources that explain or interpret primary sources.
questions.tip: Primary: Code, Regs, Rulings, Cases. Secondary: everything else (treatises, articles, publications).

questions.question: The highest authority in federal tax law is:

options.B: The Internal Revenue Code

questions.explanation: The Internal Revenue Code (IRC), enacted by Congress, is the highest statutory authority for federal tax law. Only the U.S. Constitution and tax treaties can override the Code. All other sources (regulations, rulings, cases) interpret or apply the Code.
questions.tip: Constitution > Treaties > IRC > Regulations > Rulings > Cases (persuasive authority varies by court).

questions.question: Revenue Rulings represent:

options.A: Changes to the Internal Revenue Code
options.B: The IRS's interpretation of how law applies to specific fact situations

questions.explanation: Revenue Rulings are official IRS interpretations of how the tax law applies to specific fact patterns. They are published for guidance and can be relied upon by taxpayers. While not as authoritative as the Code or regulations, they indicate the IRS position on an issue.
questions.tip: Revenue Rulings: IRS position on specific facts. Published in Internal Revenue Bulletin. Can be relied upon.

questions.question: Legislative regulations issued under a specific grant of authority from Congress carry:

options.B: The force and effect of law

questions.explanation: Legislative regulations are issued under specific Congressional authority (e.g., Section 1502 consolidated return regulations). They have the force and effect of law and are nearly impossible to challenge. Interpretive regulations explain the Code and can be challenged if they contradict the statute.
questions.tip: Legislative regs = force of law (specific Congressional grant). Interpretive regs = can be challenged if unreasonable.

questions.question: To file a case in the U.S. Tax Court, a taxpayer must:

options.B: Receive a notice of deficiency from the IRS

questions.explanation: Tax Court is a pre-payment forum—taxpayers can challenge deficiencies without first paying. However, a statutory notice of deficiency (90-day letter) from the IRS is required to establish jurisdiction. The petition must be filed within 90 days of the notice.
questions.tip: Tax Court: no prepayment, but need 90-day letter. District Court/CFC: must pay first, then sue for refund.

questions.question: A private letter ruling:

options.A: Can be relied upon by any taxpayer with similar facts
options.B: Is binding only on the taxpayer who requested it for the specific transaction

questions.explanation: A private letter ruling (PLR) is the IRS's response to a taxpayer's request for guidance on how the law applies to their specific proposed transaction. It is binding only on that taxpayer for that transaction. Other taxpayers cannot rely on it but may find it useful as an indicator of IRS position.
questions.tip: PLR: binding only on requesting taxpayer. Can't cite as authority. Useful for insight into IRS thinking.

questions.question: Tax Court decisions are appealable to:

options.B: The U.S. Court of Federal Claims
options.C: The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the taxpayer's circuit

questions.explanation: Tax Court decisions are appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the circuit where the taxpayer resides. District Court decisions also go to the Circuit Court of Appeals. Court of Federal Claims decisions go to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Ultimate appeal is to the Supreme Court.
questions.tip: Tax Court/District Court → Circuit Court of Appeals. CFC → Federal Circuit. All → Supreme Court (if cert granted).

questions.question: Temporary Treasury regulations:

options.A: Have no legal effect until finalized
options.B: Have the same force as final regulations but expire after 3 years
options.D: Cannot be relied upon by taxpayers

questions.explanation: Temporary regulations have the same legal force as final regulations but are time-limited, typically expiring within 3 years. They are issued when immediate guidance is needed and are published simultaneously as proposed regulations to invite public comment before finalization.
questions.tip: Temporary regs: full legal effect, 3-year limit. Proposed regs: no legal effect, just for comment.

questions.question: Under the Golsen rule, the Tax Court will follow:

options.A: Its own precedent regardless of circuit court rulings
options.B: The ruling of the circuit court to which the case is appealable

questions.explanation: Under the Golsen rule, the Tax Court follows the precedent of the circuit court to which the taxpayer's case is appealable, even if the Tax Court disagrees. This ensures consistency in application within each circuit. If no circuit precedent exists, the Tax Court follows its own analysis.
questions.tip: Golsen: Tax Court follows taxpayer's circuit. Important for forum shopping when circuits differ.

questions.question: Revenue Procedures primarily address:

options.B: Internal IRS practices and procedures for tax administration

questions.explanation: Revenue Procedures describe internal IRS practices and procedures, including how taxpayers should interact with the IRS, safe harbors, and procedural matters. Examples include procedures for filing ruling requests, automatic accounting method changes, and late election relief.
questions.tip: Revenue Procedures = how to do something (procedures). Revenue Rulings = how law applies to facts (substance).

questions.question: Tax Court small case (S case) procedures apply when the disputed amount is:

options.A: $25,000 or less for any tax year
options.B: $50,000 or less for any tax year
options.C: $100,000 or less for any tax year
options.D: Any amount if the taxpayer elects

questions.explanation: Small case procedures are available when the amount in dispute is $50,000 or less per tax year. The procedures are less formal, decisions are final (no appeal), and opinions are not published as precedent. This provides an accessible forum for smaller disputes.
questions.tip: S case: ≤$50,000, informal, no appeal, not precedent. Regular case: appealable, may be precedent.

questions.question: Congressional committee reports are useful in tax research because they:

options.B: Explain Congressional intent behind statutory language

questions.explanation: Committee reports (House Ways and Means, Senate Finance, Conference) explain Congress's intent when enacting tax legislation. While not binding law, courts give weight to legislative history when statutory language is ambiguous. The Conference Report is particularly important when resolving differences.
questions.tip: Committee reports: explain intent. Useful for ambiguous statutes. Conference Report resolves House-Senate differences.

questions.question: A Tax Court Memorandum decision:

options.B: Applies established law to a particular set of facts
options.D: Is only issued in S cases

questions.explanation: Memorandum decisions apply well-established legal principles to specific facts. Regular Tax Court decisions (TC Reports) address significant legal issues and are more likely to be cited as precedent. Both are citable, but regular decisions carry more weight for novel issues.
questions.tip: Memo = fact-driven, established law. Regular = legal issues. Both citable, regular decisions more authoritative.

questions.question: Chief Counsel Advice memoranda are:

options.B: Written legal advice from IRS counsel to field offices, released to the public

questions.explanation: Chief Counsel Advice (CCA) includes Field Service Advice, Technical Assistance, and Litigation Guidance memos. They must be released to the public but cannot be cited as precedent. They provide insight into IRS legal positions and strategies.
questions.tip: CCA: public but not precedent. Shows IRS thinking. Include Field Service Advice and Technical Advice.

questions.question: For penalty protection, substantial authority includes:

options.B: The Code, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, and certain other sources
options.C: Any source the taxpayer finds persuasive

questions.explanation: Substantial authority includes: the IRC, legislative history, regulations, revenue rulings/procedures, tax treaties, court cases, Congressional intent, IRS notices/announcements, and private letter rulings/TAMs (only for the taxpayer to whom issued). Secondary sources like treatises are excluded.
questions.tip: Substantial authority sources listed in regulations. Does NOT include: IRS publications, textbooks, articles.

questions.question: Proposed Treasury regulations:

options.B: Have no legal effect but indicate future IRS position

questions.explanation: Proposed regulations have no legal effect—they are issued for public comment before finalization. However, they indicate the Treasury's interpretation and likely future position. Final regulations may differ based on comments received. Taxpayers rely on proposed regulations at their own risk.
questions.tip: Proposed = no legal effect, just preview. Comment period required before finalization.

questions.question: A taxpayer might choose the Court of Federal Claims over Tax Court because:

options.B: The CFC follows national (Federal Circuit) precedent rather than regional circuits
options.C: The CFC has no filing fee
options.D: The CFC decisions cannot be appealed

questions.explanation: The CFC follows Federal Circuit precedent, which may differ from regional circuits. A taxpayer might prefer CFC if Federal Circuit precedent is favorable. Tax Court follows the taxpayer's regional circuit (Golsen rule). District Court follows its regional circuit as well.
questions.tip: Forum shopping: consider which precedent applies. CFC = Federal Circuit. Tax Court/District = regional circuits.

questions.question: When the IRS acquiesces to a court decision, it means:

options.A: The IRS will appeal the decision
options.B: The IRS accepts the decision and will follow it in similar cases
options.D: The IRS will seek legislative change

questions.explanation: Acquiescence (acq.) means the IRS accepts the court's decision and will follow it in handling similar cases. Nonacquiescence (nonacq.) means the IRS disagrees and will continue to litigate the issue. An action on decision (AOD) may explain the IRS's reasoning.
questions.tip: ACQ = IRS accepts, will follow. NONACQ = IRS disagrees, will continue to litigate issue.

questions.question: The citation 'IRC §162(a)(1)' refers to:

options.A: Section 162, subsection (a), paragraph (1) of the Internal Revenue Code
options.B: Treasury Regulation 162

questions.explanation: IRC §162(a)(1) is the citation format for the Internal Revenue Code: section number (162), subsection (a), and paragraph (1). This section allows deductions for ordinary and necessary business expenses. Understanding citation formats is essential for tax research.
questions.tip: IRC § = Code section. Treas. Reg. § = regulation. Rev. Rul. = Revenue Ruling. T.C. Memo = Tax Court Memo.

questions.question: IRS Notices are typically used to:

options.B: Provide interim guidance on new legislation or announce upcoming regulations

questions.explanation: IRS Notices provide interim guidance pending issuance of regulations, announce the IRS's position on emerging issues, or describe regulations to be issued. They are published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin and can be relied upon by taxpayers.
questions.tip: Notices: interim guidance, pending regulations, emerging issues. Published in IRB. Can be relied upon.

questions.question: A taxpayer might prefer U.S. District Court because:

options.A: No prepayment of tax is required
options.B: A jury trial is available
options.D: The judge has specialized tax expertise

questions.explanation: District Court is the only forum offering jury trials in tax cases. This may benefit a taxpayer with sympathetic facts. However, the taxpayer must pay the disputed tax first and sue for a refund. District Court judges are generalists, not tax specialists.
questions.tip: District Court: jury trial available, must prepay tax. Tax Court: no jury, specialized judges, no prepayment.

questions.question: Under Chevron deference, courts reviewing Treasury Regulations:

options.B: Defer to reasonable agency interpretations when the statute is ambiguous

questions.explanation: Under Chevron deference, if the statute is ambiguous, courts defer to the agency's reasonable interpretation. If the statute is clear, the agency must follow it. More recent cases have refined this, with less deference to interpretive regulations that weren't subject to notice-and-comment rulemaking.
questions.tip: Chevron: ambiguous statute + reasonable interpretation = deference. Clear statute = no deference needed.

questions.question: When a Treasury Regulation conflicts with the plain language of the IRC:

options.B: The statute controls because it is higher authority
options.D: The taxpayer may choose which to follow

questions.explanation: The Internal Revenue Code, enacted by Congress, is higher authority than Treasury Regulations, issued by the executive branch. If a regulation conflicts with clear statutory language, the statute controls. Regulations must be consistent with the statute to be valid.
questions.tip: Code > Regulations. Regulation contradicting clear statutory language is invalid.

questions.question: The U.S. Supreme Court hears tax cases:

options.A: Automatically on appeal from any court
options.B: Only by writ of certiorari, typically to resolve circuit court conflicts
options.C: Only when requested by the IRS
options.D: In all cases involving over $1 million

questions.explanation: Supreme Court review is discretionary through certiorari. The Court typically grants cert when there are circuit splits (different courts reaching different results) or significant federal questions. Very few tax cases reach the Supreme Court, but its decisions are binding on all courts.
questions.tip: Supreme Court: certiorari, resolves conflicts, rarely grants. Decisions bind all courts and the IRS.

questions.question: A Technical Advice Memorandum (TAM) is:

options.A: The same as a Revenue Ruling
options.B: Written guidance from the National Office to a field office on a specific taxpayer's case
options.C: Published for all taxpayers to rely upon

questions.explanation: TAMs provide guidance from the IRS National Office to field personnel on specific, usually complex or controversial, issues during audits. They are binding on the IRS for that taxpayer's issue but cannot be cited as precedent by others. They are released to the public in redacted form.
questions.tip: TAM: National Office guidance on audit issue. Binding on IRS for that taxpayer. Public but not precedent.

questions.question: The proper sequence for tax research is:

options.A: Check regulations, then the Code, then cases
options.B: Gather facts, identify issues, locate authority, analyze, conclude, and communicate
options.C: File the return, then research if audited
options.D: Find supporting authority, then identify facts

questions.explanation: Tax research follows a structured process: (1) gather relevant facts, (2) identify tax issues, (3) locate applicable authority (Code, regulations, cases), (4) analyze how authority applies to facts, (5) reach conclusions, and (6) communicate findings. Facts drive the analysis.
questions.tip: GILAC: Gather facts, Identify issues, Locate authority, Analyze, Conclude/Communicate. Facts first!

questions.question: When a tax treaty conflicts with the Internal Revenue Code:

options.B: The Code always controls

questions.explanation: Treaties and the IRC are at the same level under the Constitution. When they conflict, the later-enacted provision generally controls (later-in-time rule). However, Congress typically includes treaty override language in legislation, and courts try to harmonize where possible.
questions.tip: Later-in-time: later statute or treaty prevails. Congress often includes explicit override language.

questions.question: Under the doctrine of stare decisis, a court generally:

options.A: Must follow all prior case law regardless of jurisdiction
options.B: Follows precedent from courts with appellate authority over it

questions.explanation: Stare decisis means courts follow precedent from courts with appellate authority. A district court follows its circuit and Supreme Court. Tax Court follows the taxpayer's circuit (Golsen) and Supreme Court. Decisions from other circuits are persuasive but not binding.
questions.tip: Stare decisis: binding precedent from higher court in same chain. Other circuits = persuasive only.

questions.question: A determination letter from the IRS:

options.A: Is the same as a Revenue Ruling
options.B: Is issued by a local IRS office on completed transactions applying established principles
options.C: Cannot be relied upon by the taxpayer
options.D: Is published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin

questions.explanation: Determination letters are issued by IRS field offices on completed transactions where the law is settled. Common examples include employer plan qualification letters. They differ from private letter rulings, which are issued by the National Office for proposed transactions or novel issues.
questions.tip: Determination letter: field office, completed transaction, settled law. PLR: National Office, proposed transaction, uncertain law.

questions.question: A tax citator is used to:

options.B: Verify that cited authority is still valid and find related authorities

questions.explanation: Citators (like RIA Checkpoint or CCH Intelliconnect) show whether cases have been affirmed, reversed, or distinguished by later courts, whether regulations have been amended, and what other authorities cite the same sources. Essential for verifying authority is still good law.
questions.tip: Citators: verify authority is still valid. Check if case was reversed, reg was amended, or ruling was obsoleted.

questions.question: Treasury Regulation §1.162-5 relates to IRC Section:

options.B: 162 (trade or business expenses)

questions.explanation: Regulation numbers follow the pattern: prefix.CodeSection-RegNumber. The prefix indicates the tax type (1 = income tax, 20 = estate tax, 25 = gift tax, 31 = employment tax). Here, 1.162-5 is income tax regulation 5 under Code Section 162 (business expenses).
questions.tip: Read reg numbers: 1. = income tax, then code section, then specific reg number. 1.162-5 = income tax, section 162, reg #5.

questions.question: IRS Announcements differ from Notices in that Announcements:

options.B: Are typically of general interest or provide administrative information
options.C: Can only be issued by the Commissioner

questions.explanation: Announcements are generally of shorter-term or narrower interest, often covering administrative matters, upcoming deadlines, or corrections. Notices typically address more substantive guidance on new legislation or policy positions. Both are published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin.
questions.tip: Announcements: administrative, short-term, corrections. Notices: substantive guidance, interim rules, policy.

questions.question: The precedential value of a court's dicta is:

options.B: Persuasive but not binding, as dicta are comments not essential to the decision

questions.explanation: Dicta (obiter dictum) are judicial comments not essential to the decision—they don't resolve the issues in the case. While potentially persuasive and indicating judicial thinking, dicta are not binding precedent. The holding (ratio decidendi) is the binding legal principle.
questions.tip: Holding = binding (essential to decision). Dicta = persuasive only (side comments, not essential).

questions.question: When beginning tax research on an unfamiliar topic, a practitioner should typically start with:

options.B: Secondary sources like treatises to gain background understanding

questions.explanation: Secondary sources (treatises, tax services, articles) provide overviews and explanations that help identify relevant primary authorities. Starting with the Code on unfamiliar topics can be inefficient. Secondary sources guide the researcher to applicable Code sections, regulations, and cases.
questions.tip: Start with secondary sources for background. Then verify with primary authority. Cite only primary.

questions.question: When evaluating conflicting authorities, more weight is generally given to:

options.B: Authority closest to the taxpayer's facts, more recent, and from higher courts

questions.explanation: When evaluating authority: (1) factual similarity matters—cases with similar facts are more relevant, (2) recency matters—more recent authority reflects current law, (3) court level matters—higher courts carry more weight, and (4) jurisdiction matters—binding authority trumps persuasive.
questions.tip: Evaluate: similar facts, recent date, higher court, binding jurisdiction. Best authority has all four.
